dt: used to express what is inevitable or seems likely to happen in the future
used to express a command or exhortation
used in laws, regulations, or directives to express what is mandatory

dt.t: it {wi}shall{/wi} be unlawful to carry firearms
he to England {wi}shall{/wi} along with you

pt: From the reams of pronouncements written about the distinction between {it}shall{/it} and {it}will{/it}—dating back as far as the 17th century—it is clear that the rules laid down have never very accurately reflected actual usage. The nationalistic statements of 18th and 19th century British grammarians, who commonly cited the misuses of the Irish, the Scots, and occasionally the Americans, suggest that the traditional rules may have come closest to the usage of southern England. Some modern commentators believe that English usage is still the closest to the traditionally prescribed norms. Most modern commentators allow that {it}will{/it} is more common in nearly all uses. The entries for {it}shall{/it} and {it}will{/it} in this dictionary show current usage.

et: Middle English {it}shal{/it} (1st & 3rd singular present indicative), from Old English {it}sceal{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}scal{/it} (1st & 3rd singular present indicative) ought to, must, Lithuanian {it}skola{/it} debt
shortdef: —used to express what is inevitable or seems likely to happen in the future

cxs.cxl: archaic present tense second-person singular of
archaic past tense second-person singular of
archaic past tense second-person singular of

dt: used to say that two things, places, etc., are very different and can never be brought together or made similar

dt.t: As far as he's concerned, work is work, family life is family life, and {it}never the twain shall meet{/it}.

shortdef: —used to say that two things, places, etc., are very different and can never be brought together or made similar
